description:
In Army Defender the player must defend his base against hordes of invading enemies. Players control a turret located at the bottom edge screen. Touching the screen makes the turret fire and there are different kinds of weapons to survive as long as possible.

The opposition consists of soldiers, tanks, parachute troopers, combat helicopters, fighter planes, bombers and elite forces. Somewhat similar to the concept of Ikaruga, enemies come in two types of colours. To hit red enemies, the turret has to be red too. The colour of the turret can be changed with a touch of the Stylus. As a last resort there is also an atomic bomb that clears everything on the screen, but it comes in limited quantity.
title: Army Defender

description:
Bejeweled Twist for DSiWare is a cut down version of the PC Original. As with the original game, you use a 'rotator' cursor to rotate jewels on the board around and make matches. Matching gems fills up the 'level up tube' on the left side of the screen and progresses you to the next level when it is full.

Unlike the original game, the DSiWare version only features two modes of play: Classic* - In this mode, the player must continue to make as many matches, filling up the 'level up tube' as much as possible. The goal is to continue doing this until they eventually receive a game over from a Bomb Gem.

  • Battle - This mode allows players to compete head-to-head locally. The DSiWare Battle mode is cross-compatible with the Nintendo DS cart version of the game.
title: Bejeweled: Twist

description:
Paper Airplane Chase is a port of the unlockable mini-game Paper Plane from WarioWare, Inc.: Mega Microgame$!. The premise is simple. Using the left and right buttons on the Control Pad, the player carefully guides a paper airplane down a tower, aiming to avoid the walls. Hitting a wall results in a game over.

The game has been expanded from its original mini-game state, and now features three modes of play: Endless* - This is the original mode of play. Continue to weave the paper plane through walls, gaps and tunnels until you eventually collide with a wall.

  • Time Attack - Choose from one of eight preset stages, and aim to reach the finish line before the current best time. Colliding with a wall results in an instant game over.

  • Race - Again, choose from one of eight preset stages. Race against a friend by sharing the DS. Player 1 uses the left and right buttons on the Control Pad, while Player 2 uses Y and A. In this mode, hitting a wall only loses time. The first player to reach the finish line wins.
title: Paper Airplane Chase

alternate_titles.title: A Little Bit of... Dr. Mario

description:
Dr. Mario Express is the portable version of Dr. Mario, a Tetris-like puzzle game with a hospital theme. The object of the game is to destroy all the colored viruses in the jar by throwing pills in and then lining them up to the viruses. Lining up four pill pieces or viruses horizontally or vertically clears them from the playfield.

There are two modes of play:* Classic - Choose your game's starting level, game speed, and song. The game will start with your preferences, and each level will finish when all the viruses are gone. The player then progresses onto the next level.

  • Vs. CPU - Choose your starting level and speed, as well as the CPU's starting level and intelligence. The game finishes when one player wins by clearing their viruses, or the opponent loses by having their pills run to the top of the bottle.
title: Dr. Mario Express

alternate_titles.title: Mario vs. Donkey Kong: Die Rückkehr der Mini-Marios!

description:
Mario vs. Donkey Kong: Minis March Again! is an action/puzzle game similar to the previous game in the series. However, rather than using gesture-based controls to guide the Mini-Mario toys, they are now activated by tapping them or being bumped by other toys. Once the Minis start, they cannot stop (much like in Lemmings, and it's up to you to guide them to the exit and protect them from enemies and obstacles. Before the level starts, you can examine the layout and prepare game pieces so that you can guide the Minis to safety.

Even though you cannot control the Minis directly, you can move blocks around by tapping them with the stylus, allowing you to create steps, bridges and walls. Certain objects, such as conveyor belts, springs and walls can also be adjusted to block or guide the Minis. If a Mini bumps into an enemy, spikes or falls too far, they will break. In addition to this, once the first Mini goes through the exit door, the other Minis must reach it within a certain time or the door will close without them. The final level before the boss features a Locked Door - one of the Minis has a key, and you must guide them to the door first to unlock it and allow the other Minis to enter. After completing all the main levels in each world, you must face off against Donkey Kong. Your goal is to use the Mini Marios as ammo to shoot him and take down his health to beat him and progress to the next stage.

The game also features a level editor. As you progress through the levels, you can use new level templates based on the worlds you have completed.
title: Mario vs. Donkey Kong: Minis March Again!

description:
Photo Dojo is a 2-D fighting game developed by Nintendo. It's main point is to create a fighter by putting yourself in the game, literally. Creating a character is accomplished using the Nintendo DSi camera. Your character is created by taking 13 pictures of either yourself or your friend in different prearranged fighting poses ranging from jumping to throwing a fireball. A fighter is not complete without his or her own sound effects, and this is where your DSi microphone comes into play, letting you record different dialogue such as your punching noises to your victory speech. The stages in which you fight on are also your own, and can be taken using the DSi camera.

After creating a fighter you are able to play one of two modes in the game. The first is Vs. mode, where you can battle with your own character against a friend also using his own character. Two player fighting with a friend is limited to using one Nintendo DSi, so player one will use the L-Shoulder and Directional Pad and player 2 will use the R-Shoulder and face buttons. The next mode is called Story mode and it's main premise is to take one of your created characters and face off against a wave of 100 of your other created characters. Beating all 100 characters in Story Mode will unlock a new game track which you can use when starting up a match.
title: Photo Dojo

description: Ball is a DSiWare game based on the Game & Watch LCD toy of the same name. You play as a juggler who is juggling balls. The DSiWare version mimics the LCD look with the "ghost" images that you can see in addition to the lit up images. There are two different modes of play - in GAME A, you juggle two balls, while in GAME B, you alternate between three. Each time you catch a ball, your score increases by one point. When you drop a ball, the game ends.
title: Game & Watch: Ball

description:
Flagman is a DSiWare game based on the Game & Watch LCD toy of the same name. You watch a person who raises flags and his feet, each which has a corresponding number. In GAME A, you repeat the pattern after the Flagman in a Simon-style game. In GAME B, you must raise the correct flag after the Flagman has finished raising his. You earn a point for each flag you raise correctly.

A timer on the right-hand side of the screen drains, and if it empties completely, you lose a life. You also lose a life if you make a mistake. Lose all of your lives, and the game is over.
title: Game & Watch: Flagman

description:
Donkey Kong Jr. is a DSiWare game based on the Game & Watch LCD toy of the same name. In this game, you play as Jr., who must rescue his father, Donkey Kong, from Mario, who has captured him and locked him in a cage. Mario is setting off Snapjaw traps to thwart you, and you'll have to dodge the birds too as you jump and climb vines to reach the hanging key and jam it in the lock. Do this four times in succession, and you'll remove all of the cage sections, freeing DK from his prison, earning you a 20 point bonus.

You'll score a miss if you run into a Snapjaw, a bird, or mistime the jump to the key and fall to the ground. If you get three misses, your game is over. At 300 points, all of your misses will clear, and if you have no misses, all the points you earn will double until you score a miss.
title: Game & Watch: Donkey Kong Jr.

description:
Manhole is a DSiWare game based on the Game & Watch LCD toy of the same name. All of the manhole covers are missing along the footpaths in the street, and it's up to you to cover them up as people walk across so that they don't fall into the sewer below.

You score a point for each person that you prevent from falling, and each person that falls scores you a miss. When you have three misses, the game is over. If you reach 300 points, all of your misses are cleared - if you have no misses, then all of your points are doubled until you do eventually score a miss.
title: Game & Watch: Manhole

description:
Chef is a DSiWare game based on the Game & Watch LCD toy of the same name. You play as a chef who is juggling multiple pieces of food in the air with his skillet. You'll need to be quick to make sure that they all stay in the air. Occasionally, a cat on the side of the screen will snag one of the food items and hold it in place for a random time, and then let go, just to make things more difficult.

You score 1 point for each piece of food that you catch. You score a miss when you drop a piece of food on the ground. When you score three misses, the game is over. If you reach 200 points, all of your misses will clear - if you have no misses when you reach 200 points, your points will double until you score a miss.
title: Game & Watch: Chef

description:
Helmet is a DSiWare game based on the Game & Watch LCD toy of the same name. For some reason, tools such as hammers, pliers and wrenches are raining from the sky. It's your goal to make sure that you don't get hit on the head by these falling tools. For every three tools that you avoid, you'll score a point. There's also a garden shed that occasionally opens briefly - you can run inside there for safety as well as five bonus points.

Every time you get hit on the head with a tool, you'll score a miss. If you score three misses, your game is over. At 200 and 500 points, all of your misses clear, however, if you have no misses during this time, your points will be doubled until you eventually score a miss.
title: Game & Watch: Helmet

description: Judge is a DSiWare game based on the Game & Watch LCD toy of the same name. Unlike many other Game & Watch games, it can be played with either one or two players. Two characters holding mallets stand opposite each other. Numbers appear on two large signs above them (between 1 and 9). If your number is the same or higher than your opponent's, whack them with your mallet. If it's lower, dodge out of the way. The first player to react scores a point. The first player to 99 points wins.
title: Game & Watch: Judge

description:
Mario's Cement Factory is a DSiWare game based on the Game & Watch LCD toy of the same name. You play as Mario, who is working in a cement factory. Conveyor belts at the top of the screen drop cement into tubs below. Each tub can hold three lots of cement - if any more goes in, it will overflow and cover the driver of the cement truck below, scoring you a miss. You'll also score a miss if you misstep on the elevator, or get crushed at the top or bottom of the elevator shaft. If you reach three misses, the game is over.

Mario needs to manually operate the tubs' levers to open the valves and let the cement flow through to the lower level, and then into the cement truck below. Emptying cement from the upper tank scores you one point, while emptying it from the lower tank scores you two points. If you reach 300 points, all your misses will be cleared. If you have no misses when you reach 300 points, your score will be doubled until you do eventually score a miss.
title: Game & Watch: Mario's Cement Factory

description:
Vermin is a DSiWare game based on the Game & Watch LCD toy of the same name. You play as an exterminator who is preventing an invasion of moles. Moles can pop up from five different places, and it's up to you to position your hammers above them so that they'll get whacked when they pop up. You'll need to watch their tunnelling to figure out where they'll pop up from next.

You score one point for each mole that you whack. If a mole pops up and you don't hit it, you'll score a miss. Unlike most Game & Watch games, it's not possible to clear your misses in Vermin. When you reach three misses, the game is over.
title: Game & Watch: Vermin

description:
Prepare for a trip to the murky depths of the ocean with Aquia, a game in the Art Style series. In this game, you must assist a diver as he swims down further and further into the ocean. To do this, match three of the same colored blocks either horizontally or vertically, and he will descend a little. You add new blocks by scrolling your currently held blocks up and down to the desired position in the playfield, and then pressing A to push them into place (which pushes blocks out the other side). If you cause multiple blocks to clear by clearing one set of blocks and then having more blocks fall and clear, the diver will dive further.

There are two different modes of play:* Timed Dive - In this mode, you clear blocks until you reach the end of the level.

  • Free Dive - This mode continues forever - continue clearing blocks as long as you can.

Progressing through the game unlocks different creatures to view in the Aquarium. There are a total of 22 different sea creatures to unlock and view.
title: Art Style: Aquia

description:
Beans are raining down from the sky! If they land on the ground, they'll destroy the floor tiles, which is bad news for the bird, Pyoro! Destroy the beans before they hit the floor - or Pyoro is sunk!

Bird & Beans is a port of two games, Pyoro and Pyoro 2, which were both unlockable mini-games from WarioWare, Inc.: Mega Microgame$!. There are two different versions of Pyoro. In the first, Pyoro uses his elastic tongue to snag the beans before they hit the ground. The higher up they are, the more points they're worth. In the second game, he uses a bullet-like seed spitting action to mow down any beans that are falling down.
title: Bird & Beans

description:
Take on the challenge of Pictobits, where you reconstruct iconic 8-bit art from an assortment of retro Nintendo titles, including Super Mario Bros., The Legend of Zelda, Wrecking Crew, Excitebike, Ice Climber and Balloon Fight. Each level plays themes from the games, remixed by popular Japanese chiptune band, YMCK. The game is heavily themed around the original NES/Famicom era.

In Pictobits, both screens are used. The top screen is initially blank, while the touch screen displays the playfield and any blocks (which are called 'bits'). You can pick up to eight bits by tapping them with the stylus. You can then place them on any free place on the touch screen by letting go and tapping an empty area. Larger pieces, called 'megabits', slowly fall down from the top of the screen. These can be cleared by using bits of the same color to line up four or more horizontally or vertically, or make squares or rectangles. If you're in trouble, you can use the "POW" power to clear some of the screen of bits, but you'll be able to pick up one less bit as a result. As you clear megabits, the colors transfer to the top screen. When you have enough of each color, you reveal the secret image, which is a sprite from a Nintendo game.

As you clear megabits, you'll earn coins. Coins can be used to restore the amount of bits you can pick up as a result of using POW (each restore costs five coins). Any remaining coins get added to your game total. These coins can then be used to purchase music tracks, as well as more difficult "Dark" versions of the stages you have already cleared.

sample_screenshots.caption: I assume we all know who this is, right?

title: Art Style: Pictobits

description:
Journey to the center of the earth with Mr. Driller and his friends. Take part in three different game modes as you and your trusty drill bore through strange blocks that are appearing all over the world. Players aim the drill with the Control Pad, and drill by pressing the A Button. They'll have to keep an eye on their air as well, and collect air capsules to make sure Mr. Driller doesn't suffocate while drilling. There are also tough "X" blocks - if you try to drill these, you'll lose more air than normal.

Mr. Driller: Drill Till You Drop is a cut-down port of the Nintendo DS launch title Mr. Driller: Drill Spirits. It removes all multiplayer aspects of the game, and instead focuses on three different single player modes that were included in the original release: Mission mode* - This mode features twenty different levels based around the world, each with increasing levels of difficulty.

  • Dristone mode - In this mode (removed from the original US release of the DS version), there are no air capsules available. Instead, you can find special gems called 'Dristones'. These provide powerups ranging from destroying all blocks of a specific color to refilling your air and more.

  • Time Attack mode - In Time Attack mode, you race against the clock to complete levels.
title: Mr. Driller: Drill Till You Drop

alternate_titles.title: Elemental Master: Command the forces of Nature

description:
Elemental Masters is a trading card-based fantasy game. The land of Elendior is threatened by a great demon that has risen from the dead. The player has to survive numerous adventures, gather an army of mystical creatures and learn dark magic before he or she can face the ultimate enemy and save Elendior.

There are three different character classes available. Each class starts the game with a different magic spell. The hero travels through the land on a map and must fight numerous enemies along the way. Battles are fought by playing a trading card / board game against an AI opponent. Before the battle a deck of cards must be selected. Each card represents a creature and has four numbers corresponding to the four sides of the card. These numbers symbolize the fighting strength of the creature in that direction. The two players take turns placing their cards on a 3x3 board. If a card is put next to a weaker card (i.e. the strength or the new "attacking" card is higher than the strength of the "defending" card on their common border) the weaker card changes to the color of the attacking player. The battle ends when 9 cards have been played; the player who owns most cards on the board wins. In addition to these basic rules there are several advanced rules such as cards and board squares associated with elements (hence the name of the game), different counting modes and magic spells you can use during the battle. The winner of a battle receives one or more of the opponents cards. An important aspect of the game is to win more and stronger cards and learn new magic spells.

sample_screenshots.caption: The end of the battle - the Siren is defeated!
On the black market you can trade a stack of weaker cards for one stronger card.
Even though most locations on the map are battle, we discover a nice place from time to time.

title: Elemental Masters

description:
Control two characters at the same time and use two screens together to help piece a world split in half back together. Players take control of Kirra, the game's heroine, who is tasked with retrieving a mirror. When the mirror is accidentally broken, Kirra and her surroundings are split into two. To restore the world to normal, players must navigate between two screens to find the mirror's shards.

There are two primary mechanics in the game: the Reflection Mechanic and Shadow Mechanic. In both players control two characters, one on each screen, at the same time. With the Reflection mechanic, the two characters remain synchronized: objects affecting a character on one screen will affect the character on the second screen. With the Shadow Mechanic, characters are able to desynchronize from each other.

There are a total of 25 levels in the main story mode, with additional bonus levels accessible from the Level Select menu. In addition, players are able to collect journal notes hidden in the levels to learn more about the world, and can attempt a "Time Trial" mode to try and complete levels under a certain time.
title: Divergent Shift

description:
Chikkie Wowwow, the president's daughter has been kidnapped by the ghosts. It's up to Spotto, the world's most famous "Bombirdier" to hunt down the ghosts in a haunted house and rescue the girl.

Spotto! is a puzzle game in which the player takes control of Spotto, adjusting his bomb toss trajectory with the stylus to throw bombs into the ghosts’ mouths, either directly or via obstacles located throughout the environment. While ghosts and obstacles may be moving in some of the fifty stages, Spotto remains stationary in the lower left corner all the time. In the Story Mode, the player gets five bombs at the beginning of each stage and loses one for every toss that doesn't kill an enemy. After a kill, a super bomb which causes more damage, is sometimes awarded. Besides the ghosts, some boss characters will have to be beaten.

Once level 10 has been reached, it's also possible to play the Challenge Mode, where the player is given ten bombs and plays until they run out.
title: Spotto!

description:
Flipnote Studio is a drawing and animation tool. Users can use the DSi stylus to sketch, paint, and stamp drawings, and can then use the provided tools to turn their drawings into animations. Sound effects can be added using the DSi microphone, and images from the DSi camera can be inserted as well.

Users can share animations with their friends, or upload their animations to the Flipnote Hatena website and share their creations with people around the world (separate registration necessary). Users may also download animations from the Flipnote Hatena service onto their DSi.
title: Flipnote Studio

alternate_titles.title: Rittai Kakushi E Atta Kore Da
Tales in a Box: Hidden shapes in perspective!

description:
Looksley's Line Up is a hidden object game with a difference - at the start of the game, players are prompted to take a photo of their face, and then the DSi Camera uses that to track the player's movement and tilting the DSi allows to look around, up and down inside a storybook diorama, helping the rabbit Looksley find hidden objects which form part of popular fairy tales and fables such as Thumbelina, Jack and the Beanstalk, The Emperor's New Clothes and so on.

Each level in Looksley's Line Up has two different goals. The first is to find all the letters that spell that level's word, for example EAR, YES, DONKEY etc. Players can tilt the scene to line up background elements so they form letters. Then using the D-pad to move the crosshair players can collect the letters. Find all letters to complete the word. Sometimes a letter can only be formed by waiting for certain events, like background characters holding up an arc to form a complete circle.

Once all the letters are found, the level is classed as complete, and players can progress to other levels. Players can now also use that word when talking to people in the world map, which may open up different paths. The second, more difficult goal, is to find all of the different objects which are part of the fables. These can be trickier to find, as the dioramas often move and sometimes the shapes may not be visible all the time. Players can also find "hint coins", which give a hint on where to find specific objects.
title: Looksley's Line Up

description:
Wario's just opened his very own theme park, with four amazing rollercoasters! Each one of them are manned by different characters from the WarioWare franchise, with the intent of making Wario loads of cash. So roll up, and get ready for a ride like you've never had before!

WarioWare: Snapped! is the first WarioWare game created specifically for use with a camera. The game uses the Nintendo DSi's camera to control all of the microgames within each rollercoaster. At the start of the rollercoaster, you are prompted to pose for the camera, so that it can use it to track your movement and control the microgames. At the end of the rollercoaster, your results are shown, along with goofy photos of you performing the moves needed for the microgames. All of the rollercoasters require a single player, excluding Kat and Ana's, which needs to be played with two people simultaneously.
title: WarioWare: Snapped!

description:
Need for Speed: Nitro-X is a downloadable title found on the Nintendo DSi's DSiWare store.

Nitro-X is largely a revamped, downloadable version of the previously released Nintendo DS version of Need for Speed Nitro. The game features the typical arcade-style racing found in the Need for Speed series, as well as being pursued by police. Steering the car is controlled using the stylus on the touch-screen on a steering wheel pictured therein. The touch-screen also includes a map of the current race track.

The title features eighteen "supercars" from the likes of Lamborghini, Pagani, and Porsche. Gamers can also take charge of six other vehicles such as the Hummer H2 in the new Super Pursuit mode where players take the role of the pursuing cops. Racing or pursuing take place across sixteen tracks, which can be essentially doubled when raced in reverse.

Other features in the game include three "tiers" to the gameplay, a camera mode using the built-in DSi camera, the ability to win awards, and multiplayer for up to four people in local mode. A new racing mechanic called Heroic Racing makes its debut which, with carefully timed button presses, cutscenes are activated that provide dodge moves away from police or various kinds of "attacks" on opponents. Heroic Racing is activated with an on-screen meter that gives players notice that an actionable event is forthcoming.

Players can score bonus points during races by "tagging" the surrounding environment (such as with graffiti) by collecting two floating icons that appear over each track. The tagging occurs automatically once the icons are collected.
title: Need for Speed: Nitro-X

description:
Ever wish you could play fetch, but without the hassle of a dog, slobber, or requiring ample outdoor space? With Go Fetch! from the DSi Ware store, such a dream can become a reality!

The basic premise has balls being thrown about a stage, and to fetch them, the player guides a puppy to collect said balls. The challenge comes in the form of obstacles scattered about the stages--break an object with a clumsily controlled dog, and precious time is lost! Besides various fragile items in the stages, there are also distractions such as cats that can drive the puppies off-course. Besides the aforementioned balls, there may be other items present in each stage for the puppies to collect.

Go Fetch! features several locations across a generally typical urban/suburban setting with parks, schools, parking lots, beaches and the like. There's also a wide variety of dog breeds, and each has a distinct appearance and various attributes. Gameplay is performed on the bottom screen with the stylus, while the top screen shows a map of the current stage.
title: Go Fetch!

description:
21: Blackjack is a downloadable title available for the Nintendo DSi through the DSi Ware store.

21 is your pretty basic casino Blackjack game, though padded with a depth of options. Classic gameplay options exist, such as hitting, standing, or doubling down Players can modify how many decks are used, change payouts, and modify splitting options. It's even optional to have the dealer hit or stand on 17, along with more options. The title also keeps track of various stats from gameplay such as success rate, the number of Blackjacks that the player's had, and more.

The top screen of the Nintendo DS is the gameplay screen showing the cards and table, while the bottom screen is largely used for stylus/touch controls. The game is for one player.
title: 21: Blackjack

description:
Rotate the numbered balls, and line them up horizontally or vertically to make them disappear! Kuru Kuru Action Kuru Pachi 6 is a puzzle game from the Game Boy Advance title Nonono Puzzle Chairian. The rules are simple - you control a 2x2 cursor that can rotate the balls on a grid clockwise, or counterclockwise. Your job is to line up like numbered balls horizontally or vertically. Lining up three or more "3"s turns them all into "4"s, lining up four or more "4"s, turns them into "5"s, and so on, up until "6"s. When you line up six or more "6"s, they all disappear from the grid entirely.

The trick to the game is that while other lined up numbers are changing, you can still move the cursor around and rotate other numbers. This means that while one set of numbers is changing, you can prepare others to change as well. If you're quick and skilled enough, you can set off continuous combos.

Kuru Kuru Action Kuru Pachi 6 features four different modes of play:

  • Puzzle - In this mode, you must solve puzzles with a set amount of moves.
  • Time Attack - In this mode, you must clear a set amount of balls before time runs out.
  • Score Attack - In this mode, clearing balls adds to a meter, which allows you to continue playing. When the meter completely drains, it's game over.
  • Chain Challenge - In this mode, you must keep a chain going continuously. When your chain stops, the game is over.
title: Kuru Kuru Action Kuru Pachi 6

description:
Spot It! Challenge is a puzzle game built on hunting through photographic scenes to find hidden items. Think along the lines of Where's Waldo? This DSi Ware release is essentially the digital version of the Spot-It series of books from Capstone Press.

The game features ten different, carefully arranged photographic puzzles. Gameplay takes place on the bottom screen of the DS as players use the stylus to look for and tap the hidden items, as well as navigation of the image. Each of the ten puzzles is built around a different theme such as food, board games, sports, toys, etc. Standard gameplay has players racing against a clock. However, the game can be played by four players. In multiplayer--known as "Pass Around Play"--players take turns searching through a puzzle stage to see who can find ten items the fastest.

The game also features three difficulty levels--Easy, Medium, and Insane.
title: Spot It!: Challenge

description:
Alt-Play: Jason Rohrer Anthology is a collection of three games made by indie games developer Jason Rohrer. Previously these were released as freeware on the PC. The games included are:

  • Passage
  • Gravitation
  • Between

In addition to the games, the anthology also includes a biography about the author as well as a creator statement for each of the games.
title: Alt-Play: Jason Rohrer Anthology

description:
99 Bullets is a shoot-em-up with a twist--the player can take a whopping 99 hits before they die! But it's not intensity that brings about this massive hit-count--it's responsibility. The 99 hit points are also the player's ammunition count!

The game's story concerns galaxy IRATA 2601 and it coming under attack from a foe known as Black Eye. V-99 is the designation of the vague hero character--a man-shaped avatar with a retro, early 80's arcade, design aesthetic. The green wire-frame figure of V-99 features a number on the trunk of the "body" that is both a player's health and their ammunition count.

In traditional shoot-em-up fashion, players control their character, move around the screen, dodging and shooting at enemies. Rather than simply firing through swarms of enemies to finish a stage, players are tasked with earning a specific score to successfully complete a stage. This requires both carefully dodging enemies, and carefully monitoring bullet stock--along with shooting enemies to score combos. Points are earned for shooting enemies, shooting enemies without being hit by an enemy, defeating bosses, and finishing with as many bullets remaining as possible. Essentially, conservative gameplay and accuracy are the keys to success in 99 Bullets.

Players may control V-99 on both screens of the DSi or 3DS with the D-pad or the 3DS Circle Pad. Using the ABXY buttons, players may fire in four different directions, relative to the positions of said ABXY buttons.
title: 99 Bullets

alternate_titles.title: A Little Bit of... Puzzle League

description:
Puzzle League Express is a puzzle game in the vein of Tetris Attack. In the game colored blocks rise up from beneath the screen and the player must swap two blocks on the same row to make a chain of three or more of the same color. The chain is then removed and blocks fall to where it was. If further chains are created due to falling blocks, bonus points are awarded by multiplication of however many additional chains are created.

Game modes include 'Clear' where the player must remove all blocks above a marker to move on to the next stage, a timed mode called 'Score Attack', and 'Vs. com' in which the player must play against the AI, dropping blocks onto its screen with each combo.

The game ends when the tower of blocks reaches the top of the screen.
title: Puzzle League Express

description:
AiRace: Tunnel is an action game in which the player must pilot an aircraft through a cylindrical tunnel containing various hole-in-wall obstacles that spin at ever-increasing speeds.

The flight craft continuously speeds up making the levels progressively harder. The goal is to reach the end of the each tunnel-shaped level. Since the speed is controlled by the game, the player only steers - either with the control pad or the touch screen. Additionally to the five levels, which have to be unlocked in order, there is also a high-score mode which features an endless tunnel to fly through.
title: AiRace: Tunnel

description: In Art Style: KUBOS, the player must navigate an ever-hightening tower of cubes, turning each cube from grey to coloured by standing on them. The player has a limited stamina metre, when this runs out the player's avatar stops frequently to catch their breath, leaving him vulnerable to being crushed by falling cubes. Each completed floor or row of cubes replenishes the player's stamina. Cubes near the bottom of the tower will eventually be removed. The player can also push cubes around.
title: Art Style: precipice

description:
Dragon Quest Wars is a turn-based strategy game similar to Advance Wars.

Players create a team of four Dragon Quest monsters, from a selection of six and put them into battle on a grid against three teams of rival monsters. These rival teams can either be AI controlled or other players either locally or over Wi-Fi, and each team is colour-coded. The goal is to defeat all the monsters in the rival teams.
title: Dragon Quest Wars

description:
This is an spin-off edition of Kōsoku Card Battle: Card Hero, which was released a year prior on the Nintendo DS. This new edition titled Card Hero: Speed Battle Custom was released as a downloadable DSiWare game. This new adaptation uses the same battle system from Kōsoku Card Battle: Card Hero, but focuses more on pure battles with the role playing and story elements being stripped away. While there are several different CPU battles and challenges, this new version also features online battles versus other players through the Nintendo Wifi Connection.

There is a super special bonus for Card Hero fans that purchase Speed Battle Custom. If you have Kōsoku Card Battle: Card Hero in your DSi and load Card Hero Speed Battle Custom, you get 1,000 points to purchase cards from Maruhige’s shop and a rare card.
title: Card Hero: Speed Battle Custom

description:
Jibun de Tsukuru Nintendo DS Guide, which translates to My Creation: Nintendo DS Guide, is a digital tour guide utility. The downloadable DSiWare application software allows the user to create and manage digital images, sound recordings, and informatory notes about select areas or places located throughout Japan. The software allows up to ten different locations to be saved, and then it can be transferred and shared through wireless communication to any DS system being used in the area.

The software attempts to create a community created catalog of opinions and information regarding several interesting landmarks or locations for commoners or tourists to visit. Users are able to keep track of what segments of information they have experienced through a check system.

Developed by Nintendo's EAD Tokyo Group, the developers ideas was for people and businesses to create self-narrated guides for any event or location (like menus for a restaurant or information about an art exhibit).
title: Jibun de Tsukuru Nintendo DS Guide

description: Too Much Tingle Pack is a Japan-only DSiWare app featuring Tingle from the Legend of Zelda series. It features a calculator, a dancing Tingle image, a fortune teller, a timer, and a coin-flipping game. It is sold for 500 Nintendo Points.
title: Dekisugi Tincle Pack

description:
Art Style: Base 10 is a match-three dynamic puzzle game, played by rotating the console by ninety degrees. Numbers come onto the screen and must be arranged thus that a series of vertically or horizontally lined numbers adds up to 10, and will vanish by being tapped over. Numbers are able to be moved only by overturning them, and solely in pairs. That is done by rubbing the stylus along them in the according direction. When overturned, for instance, fives become twos, twos fives, eights remain eights, ones become unusable, threes remain a three if revolved vertically whilst get unusable if horizontally. Red numbers can not be moved but if one of such is removed, all of that specific number will disappear in once.

In Zerosum mode, a base of numbers lies on the right screen, new numbers arrive from the left. This game mode plays on the two screens, therefore game-over occurs when numbers have piled up to the left end of the left screen, while a level is cleared if the game field is cleared of a determined quantity of numbers.

In Puzzle mode, a certain amount of numbers is preset and none has to be left over; it is possible to restart the level if getting stuck; no time limit is given.

Infinite mode is a classic endless mode, which concludes by game over only.

The Vs mode sees two players competing with one another through local wireless (only one copy of the game is required).

A demo play mode shows to the uninitiated gamer the rudiments of each of the game modes.
title: Art Style: Base 10

description:
Art Style: Boxlife is a puzzle game. Paper squares are on the game field, visualized from a 45 degree isometric view: the player's aim is to expediently cut out and fold it, composing squares into boxes.

Apart from a tutorial mode showing the basics of gameplay to beginners, two game modes are given: R&D and Factory. The Research & Development mode works as puzzle mode: predetermined shapes of paper are given in each stage, and everything must be made into a box. Factory mode features a time limit and unlimited paper from that as many boxes as possible have to be obtained, while letting the minimum paper possible be wasted. After early levels, bombs will periodically drop onto the screen, having to be enclosed into a box and timely eliminated, otherwise the paper on every side of it will be made useless by the explosion. The score at the level's end will consider paper squandered, boxes successfully shaped and bombs burst. Results are rewarded with money, that can be used to decorate and enrich a cubic country-like environment, appearing as the protagonist's living place.
title: Art Style: Boxlife

description: Mario Clock is a Nintendo DSiWare app. It displays the time in 8-bit graphics. The user can switch between an analog and digital clock. The user can also play a game controlling Mario, depicted in the style of the original Super Mario Bros. The game involves running very fast and collecting as many coins as possible. Once 100 coins are gathered, the player changes to Luigi, and so on.
title: Mario Clock

description:
Nintendo DSi Metronome is a Nintendo DSiWare app. It features a virtual metronome, the beat and tempo of which can be adjusted. It also utilizes the microphone to help the user keep tempo. Three designs are usable, including one based on Nintendo's first handheld LCD toy in the Game & Watch series, Ball. The player can also record their own sounds via the microphone for the metronome to use.

Also included is a unique 8-bit style variant of Nintendo's 1981 arcade classic Donkey Kong. The minigame is called Donkey Kong Metronome. The goal remains the same, but with some adjustments: the players no longer controls Mario in a traditional sense. Mario moves on his own. He stops at various spots on each level when Donkey Kong starts rolling barrels at him. The player must make noise to the beat into the microphone for Mario to successfully jump over each barrel.
title: Nintendo DSi Metronome

description:
Undead Storm is an action game for the DSi and 3DS and part of the "GO Series" which is made up largely of short, very low-priced budget titles.

Undead Storm is an action game that, as is probably obvious, is about zombies. Following the Left 4 Dead school of zombie gaming, Undead Storm features four available survivors for players to choose from (all of whom play identically) as they blast away at undead hordes. All four characters appear in the stage together and fight as a team. Often, the AI-controlled characters start out injured somewhere in the level, requiring the player(s) to find them and revive them.

The game is played from a slightly-angled top-down view, and operates much like a typical Twin-Stick shooter, with the exception that players manually turn their character with the L or R buttons, and attacks are assigned to different buttons, with a pistol, a special weapon, and a throwable weapon, such as a grenade.

Unlike the aforementioned Left 4 Dead, however, players aren't trying to reach safety. Instead, players merely shoot it out in one of three stages with five waves of zombies each. There are also a few specialized zombies that mostly appear in the form of three different boss characters.

Players have a variety of weapons at their disposal, from the ever-classic shotgun, to a better pistol (the default has infinite ammo), and even a flamethrower and Molotov cocktails. These appears as drops from enemies, along with the occasional health, which when used, affects the team as a whole.

There are also 80 achievements to unlock over the course of the game, and three difficulty levels. "Completing" the game (where a player sees end credits) occurs after playing through all three stages in one sitting with a single character.
title: Undead Storm

description: This game expands on the racing sections of Puffins: Island Adventure. You control a Puffin, and have to race to the goal by flying faster than the rest of the flock. There is a total of eight race tracks, playable in four racing classes, and there are collectible power-ups along the courses.
title: Puffins: Let's Race!

description: The game expands on the fishing sections of Puffins: Island Adventure, with its protagonist being a puffin looking for fish in the Atlantic Ocean. While catching as many fishes as possible, there are larger predators, even sharks, to be wary of.
title: Puffins: Let's Fish!

description: In Puffins: Let's Roll, we help, with the Stylus, the protagonist puffin to roll over puffin eggs along icy mazes, avoiding obstacles and enemies while finding the right path, in order to reunite those with their mothers. Each course can be played trying to reach the finish in the briefest time, or to gather as many fish icons as one can within a fixed time.
title: Puffins: Let's Roll

description:
Mighty Milky Way is the second game in WayForward's Mighty series, after Mighty Flip Champs!. The player controls a cute green-skinned, pink-haired, French-speaking alien girl named Luna, who's on a secret mission throughout the galaxy. It's so secret, the game refuses to tell the player what it is. Luna flies throughout the galaxy, zooming from planet to planet. The goal of each level is to get to the black hole that will take her to the next level. There are some hazards, however. First of all, Luna can only blast off from a planet twice before it shatters. There are also some enemies. Some are stationary, but others will walk around the entire length of a planet. There are also borders surrounding each level, and often certain areas of a level, that will electrocute Luna. There are also some planets covered in spikes that will eliminate Luna if she lands on them. If Luna gets hurt even once, the level must be restarted.

All planets have a gravitational pull, including the spiky ones, and the pull is greater the bigger the planet is. Luna's main tool in navigating space is planet candy. These items can create a planet. They can be used to either create stepping stones in a large gap between planets, or to create a planet to pull Luna in before she hits a hazard. Sometimes Luna starts a level with at least one of these, and they are often scattered throughout the level, usually needing to be collected in order to progress. Other things that help Luna are meteor-like objects that are used like DK Barrels from the Donkey Kong Country series, firing Luna to far-off places, and portals, which take Luna to the same-colored portal in another area of the level.

Naturally, there is also an antagonist. At the end of each "world," T-Rex, a giant robotic dinosaur, will try to stop luna by destroying the planets she lands on with lasers. Since there is no way to fight back, Luna must simply hurry to the black hole before she has no planets to stand on. It is interesting to note that from the between-level screens, T-Rex appears to be Luna's husband.

sample_screenshots.caption: When you jump off the same planet twice, it is destroyed.
The main hub. you can visit various planets from here when you unlock them.
You are forced to do a tutorial when you first play.

title: Mighty Milky Way

description:
Nintendo DSi Instrument Tuner is, as the title suggests, a DSiWare application that helps the user to tune instruments. This can be done in one of two ways: the application can play a sample tone the user can compare to, or the user can actually play their instrument into the Nintendo DSi's built-in microphone to have the application automatically judge.

There is also a game included: Tuner Fight, loosely based on the classic Nintendo Entertainment System game Balloon Fight. In this game, balloons rise from pipes, each having a note on them. The player must make a tone into the microphone that matches the pitch of the notes on the balloons to pop them.
title: Nintendo DSi Instrument Tuner

description:
This limited edition bundle contains:

  • Pokémon Black Version
  • Black Nintendo DSi with Reshiram and Zekrom etched on the upper half
  • Nintendo DSi carrying case
title: Nintendo DSi: Reshiram & Zekrom Edition - Black (included game)

description:
This limited edition bundle contains:

  • Pokémon White Version
  • White Nintendo DSi with Reshiram and Zekrom etched on the upper half
  • Nintendo DSi carrying case
title: Nintendo DSi: Reshiram & Zekrom Edition - White (included game)

description:
Korogashi Puzzle Katamari Damacy is a puzzle game based on the Katamari franchise, with mechanics reminiscent of Pac-Attack. It revolves around stacking items and it looks like a regular falling-block puzzle game, but the pieces do not appear automatically from the top of the screen. The game is played by holding the DSi sideways, with a double portrait view, and it is played entirely on the right side. On a roster with a size of six boxes horizontally, blocks and items such as fruit need to be dropped. They appear on the right side in a preview area where they are pushed up by the cousins with a steady pace. The player selects and drags them to the roster using the stylus and then they drop down from the chosen horizontal position automatically, stacking on top of the ones below.

Every dragged item has a certain form, like an L-shape or a square of four elements. Every now and then the Prince appears. When he is dropped he follows the route that has been created with blocks to eat up the fruit and other items, creating more space so everything stacks again. This is the same mechanic as in Pac-Attack. The remaining blocks that then form a full horizontal line disappear, Tetris-style. The player needs to arrange the items in such a way that a long, interrupted passage surrounded by blocks is created for the maximum score and keeping the roster empty.

Most levels have a time limit and a goal to get a certain amount of items. These items are rolled up by the Prince using a rolling ball or Katamari, which then grows in size, show on the left screen.
title: Korogashi Puzzle Katamari Damacy

A Topsy Turvy Life: Turvy Drops
Anonymous Notes Chapter 1: From The Abyss
Anonymous Notes Chapter 2: From The Abyss
Anonymous Notes Chapter 3: From The Abyss

Jeux de plateau en images: Bluff en couleurs
Juegos de libros ilustrados: El arte del engaño
A Little Bit of... Nintendo Touch Golf

description:
This bundle includes:

  • Mario vs. Donkey Kong: Minis March Again!
  • WarioWare: Snapped!
  • Dr. Mario Express
  • Mario Calculator
  • Mario Clock
title: Nintendo DSi Bundle: Metallic Blue (included games)

description: The follow-up to Just Sing: Christmas Songs features the two Christmas songs We Wish You A Merry Christmas and Deck the Halls to karaoke to.
title: Just Sing! Christmas Vol. 2

description:
A game in the Just Sing! karaoke series that focuses on 1980s music. The songs included are:

  • Like a Virgin - Madonna
  • The Heat is On - Glenn Frey
  • Never Gonna Give You Up - Rick Astley
  • Take On Me - a-ha
title: Just Sing! 80s Collection

description: The follow-up to Just Sing! Christmas Vol. 2 features the two Christmas songs Joy to the World and Oh Christmas Tree to karaoke to.
title: Just Sing! Christmas Vol. 3

description: This minigame compilation, set in a traditional Japanese festival, contains three of the minigames from the phone game Sōhide Series: Omatsuri Dukushi. It includes the die-cutting, yo-yo fishing and sauce cracker splitting games with essentially the same gameplay and presentation as in their earlier versions.
title: Katakuri

description: Kuukiyomi DS is an updated version of the feature phone game Kuukiyomi. Like the original game, it's a social puzzle game in which players test out their ability to be considerate and read the correct thing to do in various everyday or unusual situations. The DSi version features a remixed set of 100 levels, with some of the original game's levels returning alongside new levels that use unique DS hardware features like the stylus and the microphone. Alongside the traditional 100-level set, players can also try out shortened sets of 10 levels.
title: Kuukiyomi DS

description: Doumo, DS Desu is a title created for the Nintendo Game Seminar 2009, an official Japanese Nintendo event for game design students. The game features a few small mini-games including drawing, a simple platformer, and tic-tac-toe. It contains a character based on a personified Nintendo DS narrating the story. The game was free on the Nintendo DSi Shop exclusively in Japan for a limited time.
title: Doumo, DS Desu

description: SA* is an overhead view 2D shooter with 3D graphics. While players shoot and dodge like in other shooters, its unique twist is the dash mechanic. Players can turn their ship in any direction and launch their ship forward in a slicing attack. This attack doesn't just deal damage, it also has the ability to slice enemies and scenery in half. Chopping their way through obstructions and dangerous enemy waves is the key to success.
title: Sagittarius-A-Star

description: Aquarium with Clock combines a casual aquarium simulation with a clock utility. In the aquarium mode, players can choose their fish, care for them, and decorate their aquarium to their heart's content. The clock mode provides the player with a number of different themed display options, shown right on the player's aquarium.
title: Aquarium with Clock

description: The Tower DS Classic is a cut-down, reduced-price download version of The Tower DS. It features the full game's final level paired with a new tutorial.
title: The Tower DS Classic

description: Motto Me de Unō o Kitaeru Sokudoku Jutsu Light is a Nintendo DSiware exclusive variation of the Me de Unō o Kitaeru series of speed-reading educational games. It's based on previous entries for the DS, featuring cut-down versions of their minigames and lessons.
title: Motto Me de Unō o Kitaeru Sokudoku Jutsu Light
